title.narrative: Horti-LIFE

description.narrative: A baseline will be undertaking after the inception phase when the log-frame and indicators will be finalised.
Ethio-Dutch Programme for Horticultural Development - Smallholder component

Project goals: 1. the doubling of the export sales of fresh horticulture produce from Ethiopia 2. enhanced food & nutrition security levels in the smallholder horticultural sector
This will be achieved via the following outcomes: a) more than 30,000 smallholder growers are integrated in high-value horticultural production and supply arrangements for the export or high-end domestic markets in five different regional clusters b) smallholder fruit and vegetable growers (of which at least 30% female growers) in the targeted horticultural clusters receive substantially higher net incomes (40% increase or more) c) strengthening of the existing vocational and graduate education programmes in the field of market-oriented horticulture production and supply overall pesticide use (volumes sprayed) in the smallholder horticultural sector is diminished with 30% or more e) residue levels of harmful pesticides on fresh horticultural produce from smallholders diminished with 50% or more f) enhanced capacities within MoA and other public services for the sustained support to inclusive and sustainable development of the horticultural sector

The government has prioritized horticulture as one of the growth sectors. Horticulture export firms have brought new technologies and practices to the country, and it is envisioned that smallholders can also benefit from these technologies and practices, partly also by establishing entrepreneurial relationships with these exporters, processors, high-end markets, etc. Farmers with irrigated land are expected to focus on horticulture, which allows for various crop cycles per year. The main horticulture crops, also selected by the project are: tomatoes, cabbage, hot pepper and onions.
The project is designed in 3 phases: inception (6 months), implementation (2 years) and consolidation (6 months). All 4 regions will start at the same moment.

The project targets 30,000 horticulture smallholders in total 10 woredas (districts) in Oromia, SNNPR, Amhara and Tigray regions. A smallholders has about 0.5 ha of irrigated land for horticulture production. 30% of the beneficiaries will be women.

This 3-year project will increase horticulture production with 30,000 men and women smallholder farmers in selected woredas (districts) of Oromia, SNNPR, Amhara and Tigray. Promotion of Good Agricultural Practices and Integrated Pest Management takes place through training government extension agents, farmer field schools and spray service providers, in close collaboration with the respective Bureaus of Agricutlure. Farmers will be linked with agri-business for both input and output marketing. Improved horticulture education with a special focus on IPM will take place with 8 ATVETS, on-location MScs, and PhD positions. The Mininistery of Agriculture at federal level will be supported with various TA missions.

mailing-address.narrative: Arada Sub-city, Kebele 01/02 P.O. Box 40675, Addis Ababa Ethiopia Tel.: 00251 111 262 131 Email: ethiopia@snv.org

title.narrative: Project photo
Overall pesticide use (volumes sprayed) in the smallholder horticultural sector is diminished with 30% or more
Farmers having adopted GAP including IPM among smallholders
Reduction of pesticide sales from input suppliers in horticultural clusters where pilots are implemented per estimated MT produced vegetables & fruits
More than 30,000 smallholder growers are integrated in high-value horticultural production and supply arrangements for the export or high-end domestic markets in five different regional clusters
Establishment of premium export-oriented and other high-value supply chain arrangements with smallholders (under IB)
Number of farmers newly earning from regional export (under VCD)
Number of growers for whom horticultural production is the main income-earning activity
Number of smallholder growers involved
Smallholder fruit and vegetable growers (of which at least 30% female growers) in the targeted horticultural clusters receive substantially higher net incomes
Number of female horticulture growers in the project
Average increase in farm incomes amongst smallholder horticulturalist households
Residue levels of harmful pesticides on fresh horticultural produce from smallholders diminished with 50% or more
Reduction of pesticide residue levels found on popular fruits and vegetables produced by smallholders in selected horticultural clusters with pilots
Enhanced capacities within MoA and other public services for the sustained support to inclusive and sustainabel development for the horticulture sector
Reduction in the percentage of horticultural companies and input suppliers that is not satisfied with public services
Average satisfaction score amongst farmers on DA's and other local suport services as source of information
Strengthening of the existing vocational and graduate education programmes in the field of market-oriented horticulture production and supply
